section.title: Installing Jenkins
section.para: Download jenkins.war from http://www.jenkins-ci.org. Now open a terminal and execute java -jar jenkins.war. This will initiate Jenkins in port 8080 by default (if you need to change that port, use --httpPort=9999).
Jenkins creates a default workspace for you at ~/.jenkins or it uses the folder specified in JENKINS_HOME environment variable.

Go to http://localhost:8080 to check if your installation is working. We will call this page as main screen from now on. The examples in this tutorial require you to have administrator rights in Jenkins.

section.title: Installing and configuring Jenkins TestLink Plug-in
section.para: The plug-ins in Jenkins are distributed from a central update site. Select the option Manage Jenkins in the left menu and look for the Manage Plugins option. Clicking on Available will bring you the list of plug-ins ready to be installed in your Jenkins installation.

Just check the check box besides the plug-in name on the list and click on Install to install the plug-in. Jenkins will download and install the plug-in automatically for you. Restart Jenkins to enable your plug-in.

After restarting Jenkins, go to Manage Jenkins again, this time click on Configure System option and look for the TestLink section. Fill the TestLink configuration form with a name for your TestLink installation, the URL of the XML-RPC API and your devKey.

By default the TestLink XML-RPC API URL is http://<host>:<port>/lib/api/xmlrpc.php. The devKey can be obtained by entering TestLink, clicking on My Settings (top menu) and generating a new devKey, if there is none yet. If you cannot see the API interface section in My Settings page, then it is very likely that you didn't enable it yet. Go back to to review your work.

section.title: Creating a job in Jenkins
section.para: In order to create a new job all that you need to do is click on New Job and give it a name. Choose the option to create a Free-style project.

Our job will use git to retrieve the test automation project. This is the project mentioned in , and can be found at https://github.com/kinow/jenkins-testlink-plugin-tutorial. In a real world project you probably will use a SCM (SVN, Git, CVS, etc) to store your test automation project.

Click on Add build step button to expand its options and then click on Invoke TestLink. It will show a new form with options to integrate your Jenkins job with TestLink. The plug-in configuration screen contains three sections: TestLink Configuration, Test Execution and Result Seeking Strategy. To fill this form, we will use the configuration created in TestLink throughout .

section.title: TestLink Configuration
section.para: In this section, you are asked to provide the configuration that the plug-in will use to connect to TestLink and retrieve the data for your automated tests.
Use the following settings for this section:

row.entry: Select the version that you created in the global configuration

section.title: Test Execution
section.para: This section contains the configuration to execute your automated tests. You can add Single Build Steps, which are executed once per build, or Iterative Build Steps, which are executed once per automated test found in TestLink.
There is an advanced section, that is hidden by default, with extra hooks.
Use the following settings for this section:

row.entry: Add an Invoke top-level Maven targets build step, and as goals use test -DsuiteXmlFiles=suite.xml
Leave it the way it is

section.title: Result Seeking Strategy
section.para: Finally, here you can configure the Result Seeking Strategy. The plug-in implements the Strategy pattern for seeking test results. What means that depending on your configuration, the plug-in might use certain algorithm for parsing and updating test results in TestLink.
Each strategy can have different settings. You can use more than one strategy, but you will have to take care to not have the same test in two different strategies.
Use the following settings for this section:

section.para: Save your job.

section.title: TestLink Version
section.para: This is the name of your TestLink installation in Jenkins global configuration.

section.title: Test Project Name
section.para: This is the name of your Test Project in TestLink. You can use environment variables in this field.

section.title: Test Plan name
section.para: This is the name of your Test Plan in TestLink. You can use environment variables in this field.

section.title: Build Name
section.para: This is the name of your Build in TestLink. You can use environment variables in this field.

section.title: Single Build Steps
section.para: These Build Steps are executed only once in the job execution.

section.title: Iterative Test Build Steps
section.para: These Build Steps are executed iteratively for each test case retrieved from TestLink. For these Build Steps, a set of environment variables are available. We will discuss more about them soon.

section.title: Test Result Seeking Strategies
section.para: This is the Result Seeking Strategy chosen to seek and update test results in TestLink.

section.title: Include pattern
section.para: The plug-in uses this pattern to find test results of your tests execution (single test command or iterative). It supports Ant-like expressions like TEST*.xml or target/**/testng*.xml.

section.title: Key Custom Field
section.para: This is the custom field used by the plug-in to link a test case in TestLink with your test results. This custom field must exist in the list of custom fields.

section.title: Attach TestNG XML
section.para: If this option is checked the plug-in will attach the TestNG XML file to TestLink execution. This way you can open the XML in TestLink.

section.title: Mark skipped test as Blocked
section.para: By default, in TestNG, skipped tests are not updated in TestLink. It means that they appear as Not Run in TestLink. If this option is checked, the plug-in updates the test case in TestLink as Blocked.

section.title: Environment variables
section.para: The plug-in retrieves all the information from TestLink for your Test Project, Test Plan, Build and automated Test Cases. You can then use any of this information to execute your tests. Jenkins itself provides the Environment Variables, plus Build Environment Variables (such as BUILD_ID, which holds the date time of your job).

The plug-in injects the information retrieved from TestLink as extra environment variables. This way you can use the value of the Java class custom field value that you created in in any of your iterative Build Steps. Below you can find an example of how to execute a single test with Maven and one of these environment variables.

As you can see, our test command uses the Java class custom field value to specify the name of the test to Maven (Maven Surefire Plug-in, actually). Below you will find a list with the information that the plug-in makes available for your job configuration. As custom fields names may vary, the strategy used is capitalize the custom field name, replace spaces with _ and append it to TESTLINK_TESTCASE_, which represents information of a Test Case in TestLink.
